article.heading: Vocals and lyrics
article.paragraph: Traditional black metal bands usually use raspy, high-pitched vocals which include shrieking, screaming and snarling,sfnKahn-Harris20074a vocal style influenced byQuorthonofBathory (band)Bathory.sfnOlson200818fDeath growls, common in thedeath metalgenre, are sometimes used, but less frequently than the characteristic black metal shriek.Cite bookThe SAGE Handbook of Popular Musichttps://books.google.com/books?idSAGE2015-01-199781473914407AndyBennettSteveWaksman458Cite bookDeleuze and Musichttps://books.google.com/books?idEdinburgh University Press2004-01-019780748618699IanBuchananMarcelSwiboda107

Black metal lyrics typically attack Christianity and the other institutional religions,often using apocalyptic language.SatanismSataniclyrics are common,cite videoDomeMichael2007Murder Music: Black Metalmotion pictureRockworld TVand many see them as essential to black metal. For Satanist black metal artists, "Black metal songs are meant to be like Calvinist sermons; deadly serious attempts to unite the true believers".sfnOlson200825Misanthropy,global catastrophe, war, death, destruction and rebirth are also common themes.Another topic often found in black metal lyrics is that of the wild or harsher aspects of nature particularly the wilderness, forests, mountains, winter, storms and blizzards. Black metal also has a fascination with the distant past. There are many bands who write about the mythology and folklore of their homelands and promote a revival of pre-Christian, pagan traditions. For more information about black metal lyrics, see the#Ideologyideology sectionbelow.

article.heading: Imagery and performances
article.paragraph: Many bands choose not to play live.Marc Spermeth:Besessen von der Dunkelheit und dem Bsen. In:Ablaze, no. 5, May/June 1995, p. 12.Ben Ratliff:''Thank You, Professor, That Was Putrid''. In:The New York Times, 14 December 2009.Many of those who do play live maintain that their performances "are not for entertainment or spectacle. Sincerity, authenticity and extremity are valued above all else."sfnOlson200847Some bands consider their concerts to be ritualssfnOlson200847and often make use of stage props and theatrics. Bands such asMayhemandGorgorothare noted for their controversial shows, which have featured impaled animal heads, mock crucifixions, medieval weaponry and band members doused in animal blood.cite webhttp://www.aftenposten.no/english/local/article723414.eceAftenposten Norway, Norwegian news in EnglishTisdallJonathan4 February 2004aftenposten.no4 September 2012A few vocalists are known forSelf-harmcutting themselveswhile singing onstage.

Black metal artists often appear dressed in black with combat boots, bullet belts, spiked wristbandsandCross of St. Peterinverted crossesandpentagramsto reinforce their anti-Christian or anti-religious stance.However, the most stand-out trait is their use of corpse paint black and white face paint sometimes mixed with real or fake blood, which is used to create a corpse-like or demonic appearance.

The imagery of black metal reflects its lyrics and ideology. In the early 1990s, most pioneering black metal artists had minimalist album covers featuringXerox artxeroxedblack-and-white pictures and/or writing.This was partly a reaction against death metal bands, who at that time had begun to use brightly colored album artwork.Many purist black metal artists have continued this style. Black metal album covers are typically dark and tend to be atmospheric or provocative; some feature natural or fantasy landscapes (for exampleBurzum'sFilosofemand Emperor'sIn the Nightside Eclipse) while others are violent, perverted, sacrilegious and iconoclastic (for exampleMarduk (band)Marduk'sFuck Me JesusandDimmu Borgir'sIn Sorte Diaboli).
article.heading: Production
article.paragraph: Low production quality was typical for early black metal artists with low budgets, where recordings would often be done in their homes or basements.sfnKahn-Harris20074Even when they were able to raise their production quality, many artists chose to keep making lo-fi recordings.The reason for this was to stay true to the genre's underground roots and to make the music sound more "raw" and "cold".One of the better-known examples of this is the albumTransilvanian HungerbyDarkthronea band whom Johnathan Selzer ofTerrorizer (magazine)Terrorizermagazine says "represent the DIY aspect of black metal".It was also an attempt to make black metal inaccessible to the mainstream and those who arePoseurnot committed. Many have claimed that, originally, black metal was intended only for those who were part of the scene.VocalistGaahlsaid that during its early years, "black metal was never meant to reach an audience, it was purely for our own satisfaction".

article.heading: First wave
article.paragraph: The first wave of black metal refers to those bands during the 1980s who influenced the black metal sound and formed a prototype for the genre. They were oftenspeed metalorthrash metalbands.cite bookSharpe-YoungGarryMetal: The Definitive Guide208

The term "black metal" was coined by the English band Venom with their second albumBlack Metal (album)Black Metal(1982). Although deemed thrash metal rather than black metal by today's standards,the album's lyrics and imagery focused more on anti-Christian and Satanic themes than any before it. Their music was fast, unpolished in production and with raspy or grunted vocals. Venom's members also adopted pseudonyms, a practice that would become widespread among black metal musicians.

link.part: Venom's album titled ''Black Metal (album)Black Metal'' inspired the name of the genre

article.paragraph: Another major influence on black metal was the Swedish band Bathory. The band, led by Thomas Forsberg (a.k.a.Quorthon), created "the blueprint for Scandinavian black metal".sfnMoynihanSøderlind200321Not only was Bathory's music dark, fast, heavily distorted, lo-fi and with anti-Christian themes, Quorthon was also the first to use the shrieked vocals that came to define black metal.sfnOlson200818fThe band played in this style on their first four albums:Bathory (album)Bathory(1984),The Return (Bathory album)The Return of the Darkness and Evil(1985),Under the Sign of the Black Mark(1987) andBlood Fire Death(1988). WithBlood Fire Deathand the two following albums, Bathory pioneered the style that would become known asViking metal.

Hellhammer, from Switzerland, "made truly raw and brutal music"Daniel Ekeroth:''Swedish Death Metal''. Second edition. Brooklyn, NY: Bazillion Points 2009, p. 244, accessed on 24 January 2013.with Satanic lyrics, and became an important influence on later black metal;sfnMoynihanSøderlind200310"Their simple yet effective riffs and fast guitar sound were groundbreaking, anticipating the later trademark sound of early Swedish death metal".In 1984, members of Hellhammer formedCeltic Frost,''Biography'', accessed on 24 January 2013.whose music "explored more orchestral and experimental territories. The lyrics also became more personal, with topics about inner feelings and majestic stories. But for a couple of years, Celtic Frost was one of the world's most extreme and original metal bands, with a huge impact on the mid-90's black metal scene".Tom G. Warriorof Hellhammer and Celtic Frost credited Englishhardcore punkbandDischarge (band)Dischargeas "a revolution, much like Venom", saying, "When I heard the first two Discharge records, I was blown away. I was just starting to play an instrument and I had no idea you could go so far."J. Bennett, "Procreation of the Wicked",Precious Metal: Decibel Presents the Stories Behind 25 Extreme Metal Masterpieces, Albert Mudrian, ed., Da Capo Press, pp. 34f.

article.heading: Second wave
article.paragraph: The second wave of black metal began in the early 1990s and was spearheaded by the Norwegian black metal scene. During 19901993, a number of Norwegian artists began performing and releasing a new kind of black metal music; this includedDarkthrone,Burzum,Immortal (band)Immortal,Satyricon (band)Satyricon,Mayhem (band)Mayhem,Enslaved (band)Enslaved,Thorns (band)Thorns,Gorgoroth (band)Gorgoroth,Carpathian ForestandEmperor (band)Emperor. They developed the style of their 1980s forebears into a distinct genre. This was partly thanks to a new kind of guitar playing developed by Snorre 'Blackthorn' Ruch of Stigma Diabolicum-Thorns andEuronymousystein 'Euronymous' Aarsethof Mayhem.Fenriz of Darkthrone described it as being "derived from Bathory"cite video2009[[Until the Light Takes Us]]motion pictureVariance Filmsand noted that "those kinds of riffs became the new order for a lot of bands in the '90s".Kory Grow:''WEB-EXCLUSIVE INTERVIEW: DARKTHRONE'S FENRIZ, PART 2! HIS THOUGHTS ON 'TRANSILVANIAN HUNGER' AND HIP''.The wearing of corpse paint became standard, and was a way for many black metal artists to distinguish themselves from other metal bands of the era.The scene also had an ideology and ethos. Artists were bitterly opposed to Christianity and presented themselves as misanthropic Devil worshippers who wanted to spread terror, hatred and evil. They professed to be serious in their views and vowed to act on them.Ihsahnof Emperor said that they sought to "create fear among people"sfnMoynihanSøderlind2003222and "be in opposition to society".sfnMoynihanSøderlind2003218fThe scene was exclusive and created boundaries around itself, incorporating only those who were "true" and attempting to expel all "posers".sfnOlson200830, 42Some members of the scene were responsible for a spate of church burnings and murder, which eventually drew attention to it and led to a number of artists being imprisoned.

article.paragraph: During MayJune 1991,sfnMoynihanSøderlind200366Euronymous of Mayhem opened an independent record shop namedHelvete(Norwegian languageNorwegianforhell) in Oslo. It quickly became the focal point of Norway's emerging black metal scene and a meeting place for many of its musicians; especially the members of Mayhem, Burzum, Emperor and Thorns.Jon 'Metalion' Kristiansen, writer of the fanzineSlayer, said that the opening of Helvete was "the creation of the whole Norwegian black metal scene".sfnMoynihanSøderlind200339In its basement, Euronymous founded anindependent record labelnamedDeathlike Silence Productions. With the rising popularity of his band and others like it, the underground success of Euronymous's label is often credited for encouraging other record labels, who had previously shunned black metal acts, to then reconsider and release their material.
article.heading: Dead's suicide
article.paragraph: On 8 April 1991, Mayhem vocalistPer "Dead" OhlinPer Yngve Ohlin(who called himselfDead) committed suicide while alone in a house shared by the band.cite video2007Once Upon a Time in Norwaymotion pictureAnother World Entertainmentcite video2008Pure Fucking Mayhemmotion pictureIndex VerlagFellow musicians described Dead as odd, introverted and depressed. Before going onstage he went to great lengths to make himself look like a corpse and would cut his arms while singing.Mayhem's drummer,Jan Axel BlombergHellhammer, said that Dead was the first to wear the distinctive corpse paint that became widespread in the scene.cite webhttp://www.thetruemayhem.com/interviews/previous/hh-june1998.htmInterview with Hellhammer conducted by Dmitry Basik June 1998BasikDmitriJune 1998thetruemayhem.comhttp://web.archive.org/web/20070823184104/http://www.thetruemayhem.com/interviews/previous/hh-june1998.htm23 August 20077 September 2012

He was found with slit wrists and ashotgunwound to the head. Dead's suicide note apologized for firing the weapon indoors and ended: "Excuse all the blood".sfnMoynihanSøderlind200362Before calling the police, Euronymous bought a disposable camera and photographed the body,sfnMoynihanSøderlind200349after re-arranging some items. One of these photographs was later used as the cover of a bootleg live album,Dawn of the Black Hearts.

In time, rumors spread that Euronymous had made a stew with bits of Dead's brain and had made necklaces with bits of his skull.Euronymous gave some of these necklaces to musicians he deemedworthy.He used Dead's suicide to foster Mayhem's evil image and claimed Dead had killed himself because extreme metal had becometrendyand commercialized.sfnMoynihanSøderlind200359-60Mayhem bassistNecrobutcherJrn 'Necrobutcher' Stubberudnoted that "people became more aware of the black metal scene after Dead had shot himself [...] I think it was Dead's suicide that really changed the scene".cite journalBromleyAdrian "The Energizer"Mayhem: To Hell and BackUnrestrained15http://www.thetruemayhem.com/interviews/previous/necro-unrestrained15.htmhttp://web.archive.org/web/20070823101847/http://www.thetruemayhem.com/interviews/previous/necro-unrestrained15.htm23 August 20077 September 2012

article.heading: Church burnings
article.paragraph: In 1992, members of the Norwegian black metal scene began a wave of arson attacks on Christian churches. By 1996, there had been at least 50 such attacks in Norway.Some of the buildings were hundreds of years old and seen as important historical landmarks. The first to be burnt down was Norway'sFantoft stave church. Police believeVarg Vikernesof Burzum was responsible.The cover of Burzum's EPAske (album)Aske("ashes") is a photograph of the destroyed church. In May 1994, he was found guilty for burning downHolmenkollen Chapel, Skjold Church andOld sane Churchsane Church.sfnMoynihanSøderlind200393To coincide with the release of Mayhem'sDe Mysteriis Dom Sathanas, Vikernes and Euronymous had also allegedly plotted to bombNidaros Cathedral, which appears on the album cover. The musiciansFaust (musician)Faust,sfnMoynihanSøderlind200394fSamoth,sfnMoynihanSøderlind2003141(both of Emperor) andJrn Inge Tunsberg(ofHades Almighty)sfnMoynihanSøderlind2003141were also convicted for church arsons. Members of the Swedish scene started to burn churches in 1993.sfnMoynihanSøderlind2003269f

Those convicted for church burnings showed no remorse and described their actions as a symbolic "retaliation" against Christianity in Norway.sfnMoynihanSøderlind200389Mayhem drummer Hellhammer said he had called for attacks on mosques and Hindu temples, on the basis that they were more foreign.sfnMoynihanSøderlind2003105Today, opinions on the church burnings differ within the black metal community. Many, such as Infernus and Gaahl of Gorgoroth, continue to praise the church burnings, with the latter saying "there should have been more of them, and there will be more of them".Others, such as Necrobutcher and Kjetil Manheim of Mayhem andAbbathof Immortal,see the church burnings as having been futile. Manheim claimed that many arsons were "just people trying to gain acceptance" within the black metal scene.Watainvocalist Erik Danielsson respected the attacks, but said of those responsible: "the only Christianity they defeated was the last piece of Christianity within themselves. Which is a very good beginning, of course".Black Metal Satanica, 2008.
article.heading: Murder of Euronymous
article.paragraph: In early 1993, animosity arose between Euronymous and Vikernes.sfnMoynihanSøderlind2003117On the night of 10 August 1993, Varg Vikernes (of Burzum) and Snorre 'Blackthorn' Ruch (of Thorns) drove from Bergen to Euronymous's apartment in Oslo. When they arrived a confrontation began and Vikernes stabbed Euronymous to death. His body was found outside the apartment with 23 cut wounds two to the head, five to the neck, and sixteen to the back.Steinke, Darcey. "Satan's Cheerleaders".Spin (magazine)SPIN. February 1996.

It has been speculated that the murder was the result of either a power struggle, a financial dispute over Burzum records or an attempt at outdoing a stabbing in Lillehammer the year before by Faust.cite webHueyStevehttp://music.yahoo.com/ar-257375-bioMayhem Mayhem Biography on Yahoo! He says that Euronymous had plotted to stun him with anelectroshock weapon, tie him up and torture him to death while videotaping the event.He said Euronymous planned to use a meeting about an unsigned contract to ambush him.Vikernes, Varg:''A Burzum Story: Part II - Euronymous''. article.heading: The second wave outside Norway
article.paragraph: Black metal scenes also emerged on the European mainland during the early 1990s, inspired by the Norwegian scene or the older bands, or both. InPoland, a scene was spearheaded byGravelandandBehemoth (band)Behemoth. InFrance, a close-knit group of musicians known asLes Lgions Noiresemerged; this included artists such asMtiilation,Vlad Tepes (band)Vlad Tepes, Belketre and Torgeist. InBelgium, there were acts such asAncient RitesandEnthroned. Bands such asBlack Funeral,Grand Belial's KeyandJudas Iscariot (band)Judas Iscariotemerged during this time in the United States.

A notable black metal group inEnglandat the time wasCradle of Filth, who released three demos in a black/death metal style with symphonic flourishes, followed byThe Principle of Evil Made Flesha studio album, which featured a then-unusual hybrid style of black andgothic metal. The band then abandoned black metal for gothic metal,cite bookBaddeleyGavinFilthDaniDani Filth[[The Gospel of Filth]]March 201048–50FAB Pressbecoming one of the most successful extreme metal bands to date. John Serba ofAllMusiccommented that their first album "made waves in the early black metal scene, putting Cradle of Filth on the tips of metalheads' tongues, whether in praise of the band's brazen attempts to break the black metal mold or in derision for its 'commercialization' of an underground phenomenon that was proud of its grimy heritage [...]".cite webhttp://www.allmusic.com/album/the-principle-of-evil-made-flesh-mw0000025519The Principle of Evil Made Flesh - Cradle of FilthSerbaJohn[[AllMusic]]27 August 2012Another English band called Necropolis never released any music, but "began a desecratory assault against churches and cemeteries in their area" and "almost caused Black Metal to be banned in Britain as a result".sfnMoynihanSøderlind2003316-318

article.paragraph: Regarding the sound of black metal, there are two conflicting groups within the genre: "those that stay true to the genre's roots, and those that introduce progressive elements".The former believe that the music should always beMinimalismminimalistperformed only with the standard guitar-bass-drums setup and recorded in alow fidelitystyle. One supporter of this train of thought isBlake JuddofNachtmystium, who has rejected labeling his band black metal for its departure from the genre's typical sound.cite webhttp://www.dailyherald.com/story/?idDaily Herald | Nachtmystium shines black light on black metalPizekJeff20 June 2008[[Daily Herald (Arlington Heights)|dailyherald.com]]4 September 2012Snorre Ruch ofThorns (band)Thorns, on the other hand, has said that modern black metal is "too narrow" and believes that this was "not the idea at the beginning".cite webhttp://www.voicesfromthedarkside.de/interviews/thorns.htmThornsvoicesfromthedarkside.de4 September 2012

article.heading: Ideology

link.part: Taakevocalist Hoest theCross of St. Peterinverted Christian crossis often used by black metallers to signify their opposition to Christianity

article.paragraph: Unlike other kinds of metal, black metal is associated with an ideology and ethos. It is fiercelyanti-Christian sentimentopposed to Christianityand the other mainOrganized religioninstitutional religions. Many black metal bands areSatanismSatanistsand see Satanism as a key part of black metal. Others advocate ethnic Paganism, "often coupled with nationalism",sfnMoynihanSøderlind2003313although the early Pagan bands did not call themselves 'black metal'.

Individualismis also an important part of black metal,withFenrizof Darkthrone describing black metal as "individualism above all".cite videoNorsk Black Metal2003[[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]]However, followers of Euronymous tended to be anti-individualistic,sfnOlson200827fand it has been noted that "Black Metal is characterized by a conflict between radical individualism and group identity and by an attempt to accept both polarities simultaneously".sfnOlson20082Black metal also tends to beMisanthropymisanthropicand hostile to modern society.It is "a reaction against the mundanity, insincerity and emotional emptiness that participants feel is intrinsic to modern secular culture".sfnOlson200837Aaron Weaver fromWolves in the Throne Roomsaid: "black metal is an artistic movement that is critiquing modernity on a fundamental level, saying that the modern world view is missing something".cite webhttp://www.brooklynvegan.com/archives/2009/05/an_interview_w_13.htmlAn Interview w/ Wolves in the Throne Room's Aaron Weaver22 May 2009brooklynvegan.com4 September 2012As part of this, black metal glorifies nature and has a fascination with the distant past.sfnOlson20082cite webhttp://www.chroniclesofchaos.com/articles/rants/6-668_black_metal_a_brief_guide.aspxCoC : Rant : Black Metal: A Brief GuideKalisQuentin31 August 2004[[Chronicles of Chaos (webzine)|Chronicles of Chaos]]4 September 2012Sam Dunnnoted that "unlike any other heavy metal scene, the culture and the place is incorporated into the music and imagery".

In his master thesis, Benjamin Hedge Olson writes that some artists can be seen asTranscendentalismtranscendentalists. Dissatisfied with a "world that they feel is devoid of spiritual and cultural significance",sfnOlson2008129they try to leave or "transcend" their "mundane physical forms" and become one with the divine.sfnOlson20084This is done through their concerts, which he describes as "musical rituals" that involve self-mortification and taking on an alternative, "spiritual persona" (for example by the wearing of costume and face paint).sfnOlson200850
article.heading: Satanism

link.part: Thepentagramis commonly used by bands in the genre

article.paragraph: Black metal was originally a term for extreme metal bands with Satanic lyrics and imagery. However, most of the 'first wave' bands (including Venom, who coined the term 'black metal') were not Satanists and merely used it to provoke. One of the few exceptions wasMercyful Fatesinger andChurch of SatanmemberKing Diamond, whomMichael Moynihan (journalist)Michael Moynihancalls "one of the only performers of the '80s Satanic metal who was more than just aposeurusing a devilish image forshock value".sfnMoynihanSøderlind200316

In the early 1990s, many Norwegian black metalers presented themselves as genuine Devil worshippers.sfnOlson20087fMayhem's Euronymous was the key figure behind this.sfnOlson200827fThey attacked the Church of Satan for its "freedom and life-loving" views;Esa Lahdenpera:''Northern Black Metal Legends''. In:Kill Yourself, no. 2, August 1993. Retrieved 30 January 2013.thetheistic Satanismthey espoused was an inversion of Christianity. Benjamin Hedge Olson wrote that they "transform[ed] Venom's quasi-Satanic stage theatrics into a form of cultural expression unique from other forms of metal or Satanism" and "abandoned the mundane identities and ambitions of other forms of metal in favor of religious and ideological fanaticism".sfnOlson200827fSome prominent scene memberssuch as Euronymous and Fauststated that only bands who are Satanists can be called 'black metal'. Bands with a Norwegian style, but without Satanic lyrics, tended to use other names for their music.cite journalHalupczokMarcWaldschrate & Met-Trinker[[Metal Hammer]]March 201030cite book[[Frost (album)|Frost]]CD liner notes[[Osmose Productions]]1994cite bookNordic Metal – A Tribute to EuronymousCD liner notes[[Necropolis Records]]1995This view is still held by many artists such asInfernus,cite webhttp://www.live-metal.net/features_interviews_infernus_gorgoroth.htmllive-metal.net - Interviews: Gorgoroth - InfernusMakiJeff18 July 2006live-metal.net4 September 2012Daniel RostnArioch,Dr. Rape:Funeral Mist. In: Jon Kristiansen:Metalion: The Slayer Mag Diaries.Brooklyn, New York: Bazillion Points Books 2011. pp. 420f.Nornagestand Erik Danielsson.cite webhttp://www.geocities.com/flesh_ro/watain.htmInterview with WatainArthurgeocities.com/flesh_ro4 September 2012yeshttps://web.archive.org/20091019170513/http://geocities.com/flesh_ro/watain.htm19 October 2009Some bands, like the reformed Dissectionand Watain,terrybezer:''Unpublished Watain Interview Extras!'', 27 March 2009, accessed on 21 November 2012.insist that all members must be of the same Satanic belief, whereas Michael Ford ofBlack Funeral''Black Funeral''. ''Embrace The Sounds Of Grim Medieval Vampiric Black Metal...''. In:Kill Yourself!!! Magazine, no. 3, 1995, p. 36, accessed on 21 November 2012.and MkM ofAntaeus (band)AntaeusOphth:''AntaeuS'', accessed on 21 November 2012.believe black metal must be Satanic but not all band members need to be Satanists. Otherssuch asJan Axel Blomberg,cite webhttp://translate.google.com/translate?hlArticle: Interview7 January 2007metallibrary.ruOpen PublishingRussian (Google-translated to English)4 September 2012Sigurd Wongravenand Eric Hornercite webhttp://www.metalunderground.com/news/details.cfm?newsidThrone of Malediction Talks the Art of Black Metal17 January 2011metalunderground.com4 September 2012believe that black metal does not need to be Satanic. An article in Metalion'sSlayerfanzine attacked musicians that "care more about their guitars than the actual essence onto which the whole concept was and is based upon", and insisted that "the music itself doesn't come as the first priority".cite journalKristiansenJon2011Worship Him!Metalion: The Slayer Mag Diaries[[Brooklyn]], New YorkBazillion Points Books467Bands with a similar style but with Pagan lyrics tend to be referred to as 'Pagan Metal' by many 'purist' black metalers.cite bookMulvanyAaron PatrickMay 2000'Re-Awakening Pride Once Lost': Indigeneity and European Folk MetalWesleyan UniversityMiddletown, ConnecticutIV

Others shun the belief in Satan, seeing it as "Judeo-Christian" in origin,Varg Vikernes:"A Burzum Story: Part III - The Lie-Propaganda". Burzum.org."Writing the deeds of Darkness and Evil". OfficialBathory (band)Bathorywebsite. Retrieved 29 October 2012.and regard Satanists as perpetuating, and playing a part in, the "Judeo-Christian" worldview."Mayhem vs. Burzum: Opposing views of black metal", Invisible Oranges, 21 September 2011.Quorthonof Bathory said he used 'Satan' to provoke and attack Christianity. However, with hisUnder the Sign of the Black MarkthirdandBlood Fire Deathfourthalbums he began "attacking Christianity from a different angle", realizing that Satanism is a "Christian product".Nevertheless, some artists use Satan as a symbol or metaphor for their beliefs. This includesLaVeyan SatanismLaVeyan Satanists(who are atheist) and others. Vocalist Gaahl, who considers himself a Norse Shaman,Tatiana Godarska:''GORGOROTH'S GAAHL INFINITE DIMENSIONS'', 19 June 2006, accessed on 28 October 2012.said: "We use the word 'Satanist' because it is Christian world and we have to speak their language [...] When I use the word 'Satan', it means the natural order, the will of a man, the will to grow, the will to become the superman".Interview with Gaahl of Gorgoroth, 7 October 2004. Tartarean Desire Webzine.Varg Vikernes called himself a Satanist in early interviews but "now downplays his former interest in Satanism", saying he was using Satan as a symbol for Odin as the 'adversary' of the Christian God.'Det Som Engang Varg'. In: Jon Kristiansen:Metalion: The Slayer Mag Diaries, p. 292.He saw Satanism as "an introduction to more indigenous heathen beliefs".sfnMoynihanSøderlind2003191Despite the high amount of Satanism in black metal, some black metal bands such asCarach Angren,Interview with Carach Angren by Heavy Metal Tribune (June 12 2012)Immortal (band)ImmortalDemonaz Interview - Immortal Interview by Justin M. NortonandEnslaved (band)EnslavedEnslaved - Music - New York Times (November 8th 2007)Director Sam Dunn Picks the Five Most Important Extreme-Metal Bands - Revolver Magazine (Aug 13th 2013)don't have Satanic-themed lyrics and have lyrics with completely different themes.
article.heading: Neo-Nazism
article.paragraph: National Socialist black metal (NSBM) is black metal by artists who promoteneo-Nazismor similar beliefs through their lyrics and imagery. Their ideology typically melds aspects of neo-Nazism orWhite nationalismwith ethnic European paganism. However, some bands meld these beliefs with Satanism or occultism. Some commentators see this ideology as a natural extension of the black metal worldview. Varg Vikernes is credited with popularizing such views within the scene,sfnMoynihanSøderlind2003303sfnOlson2008103although he now refers to his ideology as 'Odalism'.cite webhttp://www.burzum.org/eng/library/a_burzum_story07.shtmlA Burzum Story: Part VII - The Nazi GhostVikernesVargVarg VikernesJuly 2005burzum.org4 September 2012The NSBM movement began to emerge in the mid-1990s and was spearheaded by artists such as Absurd (from Germany),Graveland,Infernumand Veles (from Poland),Nokturnal Mortum(from Ukraine) andGrand Belial's Key(from USA). It is particularly strong in the formerEastern Bloc. Some black metal bands have made references to Nazi Germany for shock value, causing them to be wrongly labeled as NSBM.

NSBM artists are a small minority within black metal, according to Mattias GardellGardell, Mattias.Gods of the Blood(2003).and Benjamin Hedge Olson.sfnOlson2008123fThey have been criticized by some prominent and influential black metal artists includingJon Ndtveidt,Tormentor (musician)Tormentor,Metal Heart 2/00King ov Hell,cite webhttp://www.maelstrom.nu/ezine/interview_iss50_224.phpInterview with Jotunspormaelstrum.nuŠkotMladen20044 September 2012Infernus,Dark Funeral,cite webhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?vYouTube - Dark Funeral- Interview(Episode 276)[[YouTube]]5 April 20094 September 2012Richard Lederer (musician)Richard Lederer,cite webhttp://www.summoning.info/Stuff/PoliticalStatements.htmlPolitical Statements from Protector (Summoning)summoning.info4 September 2012Michael Ford,cite webhttp://www.fmp666.com/moonlight/blackfun2.htmlhttp://www.fmp666.com/moonlight/blackfun2.htmlfmp666.com4 September 2012andArkhon Infaustus.Some liken Nazism to Christianity in that it isAuthoritarianismauthoritarian,Collectivismcollectivist, and a "herd mentality".Olson writes that the shunning of Nazism within the scene "has nothing to do with notions of a 'universal humanity' or a rejection of hate" but that Nazism is shunned "because its hatred is too specific and exclusive".sfnOlson2008123

As a reaction to NSBM, a few black metal artists have begun promoting communism and anarchism. They refer to their music asRed and Anarchist black metal"Red and Anarchist black metal" (RABM).cite webUnearthing The Metal Underground: The Red and Anarchist Black Metal Undergroundhttp://www.metalunderground.com/news/details.cfm?newsidMetal Underground24 October 2011

article.heading: Unblack metal
article.paragraph: Since the mid-1990s, there have been a few artists who have adopted the typical black metal sound and aesthetic, but promote Christianity through their lyrics and imagery.cite journalKapelovitzDanFebruary 2001Heavy Metal Jesus Freaks - Headbanging for ChristMean Magazinehttp://www.kapelovitz.com/christianmetal.htm6 September 2007And where secular black metal thrived, so did its Christian counterpart, unblack metal, with names like [[Satanicide]], Neversatan, and Satan's Doom.harvThese artists have been labelled 'unblack metal'. The first unblack metal record wasHellig Usvart(1994) by Australian artistHorde (band)Horde. It was seen as a provocative parody of Norwegian black metal; it included song names such as "Invert the Inverted Cross" and the sole bandmember was credited as Anonymous (a pun on Euronymous). The album caused great controversy and death threats were issued against Horde. Anonymous was later revealed asJayson Sherlock. Norwegian Christian bandAntestor, formed in 1990, released the studio albumThe Return of the Black Deathin 1998, though aBootleg recordingbootlegversion of what would become its second album,Martyrium (album)Martyrium, was released in 1994.

Many in the black metal scene see "Christian black metal" as an oxymoron.On the documentaryMurder Music: A History of Black Metal(2007), all interviewed musicians stated, when asked about the matter, that black metal cannot be Christian.The term "Christian black metal" drew mocking replies from black metal musicians, for exampleMartin WalkyierofSabbat (English band)Sabbatcommented: "'Christian black metal?' What do they do? Do they build churches? Do they repair them?(laughs)".In fact, the early unblack metal groups Horde and Antestor refused to call their music "black metal" because they did not share its ethos. Horde called its music "holy unblack metal"cite webhttp://unblack.d135-1r43.de/hordeint/hordeinterview.htmlHorde Interview9 December 2007Erasmus2006Unblack.dehttp://web.archive.org/web/20071023175915/http://unblack.d135-1r43.de/hordeint/hordeinterview.html23 October 2007and Antestor preferred the term "sorrow metal".cite webMorrow, MattAntestor - The Return of the Black DeathOpen Publishing2001The Whipping Posthttp://thewhippingpost.tripod.com/antestorthereturnoftheblackdeath/6 October 2012Horde member Jayson Sherlock later said "I will never understand why Christians think they can play Black Metal. I really don't think they understand what true Black Metal is."cite webSherlockJaysonFor the life of me,...https://www.facebook.com/jayson.sherlock/posts/10200535943462750[[Facebook]]8 February 20135 February 2013However, many current unblack metal bands, such asCrimson Moonlight, feel that black metal has changed from an ideological movement to a purely musical genre, and that is why they also call their own music black metal.cite webhttp://www.ultimatemetal.com/forum/interviews/195667-crimson-moonlight-their-most-brutal.htmlCrimson Moonlight - At Their Most Brutal - Ultimate Metal ForumJordanJason24 May 2005ultimatemetal.com4 September 2012
